That's certainly not what I learnt at college. England has a huge variety of accents, all tied intimately into very pronounced social class structures. What you are probably thinking of as "the English Accent" is called Received Pronunciation or RP and originates in the Home Counties around London. For most of the 19th and 20th centuries, and to an extent now, this was the prestige accent associated with the rich and powerful wealthy enough not to actually have to live in London but who tend to cluster near it for access to Whitehall, the City, and the Royal Court. It's where one can have a stately home with 10,000 acres but still be in Lord's in time for port and cigars.
But the English settlers who first colonised North America didn't come from London or the Home Counties; they came from the area around England's major merchant port of the time, Bristol (called the West Country). The West Country accents still have pronounced terminal /r/s and long flat vowels today, like most North American accents.
So there hasn't actually been that much of a phonemic shift at all. It's just that the settlers never spoke with what you think of as "the English accent".
And as for "the influence of Irish immigrants to New York" - well, just remember that Dublin is a hell of a lot closer to Bristol than it is to New York...

This is why we're replacing analog TV signals with digital - you can squeeze a hell of a lot more into the same space. There is also a technique called multiplexing ("muxing") which carries multiple channels in the same signal by ordering packets. Your tuner knows that when you're watching channel 1 it should only listen to packet numbers 1, 7, 13 etc on a 6-channel mux. This is how satellite TV has always worked. The issue is that currently things like 4k and 8k channels sometimes require more bandwidth than the current infrastructure can stuff into one mux, which is why players like Google are investing heavily in compression technology as well as fibre - a new compression codec is hugely cheaper to roll out than a new internet backbone or satellite/receiver network.

Okay, well to address your examples: Lawrence of Arabia is a "great" biopic because of an outstanding performance from Olivier, fantastic setting and cinematography, and it's just a plain old good story; Jaws is a "great" creature feature because Spielberg understands how to take a relatively niche genre and reinvent it as something mainstream, and because of the influence his techniques have had on that genre ever since; The Godfather is a "great" gangster movie because it's not really a gangster movie at all but rather a dynastic drama with a rich script and career-making performances.
Do you see my point? There are so many different criteria that you're going to find it very difficult to pick one and say "if a film does this it's great, and if it doesn't, it's not." Even with celebrated auteurs like Kubrick or Welles, their filmographies cover a wide range of genres and styles and it's problematic to try to reengineer a formula from them. That's why they are considered "great" film-makers rather than, say, talented genre movie directors (like Michael Bay or JJ Abrams who are both very good at basically one thing).
There's a difference between being able to make excellent movies of one type over and over again, and being able to take the language and technique of film and turn it to whatever aspect of human existence you want to explore.
But to get back to your original question regarding whether goodness/greatness is objective or subjective, I would suggest that this is generally a consensus play. Of course all art and entertainment is subjective. That's what the Artistic Bargain is all about - because it happens in your brain and the artist can only create the stimulus. You have to bring the response. But if enough people perceive that there is something special about a particular piece, that tends to become "considered great".
And note that that consensus doesn't always get it right and often goes back and reconsiders because audience expectations change and it's sometimes difficult to spot what a truly game-changing film is doing until after the fact. Look at the original critical response to Alien, which was lukewarm at best, largely because most of the reviewers were not looking for a reinvention of tried-and-trusted b-movie/horror picture tropes. Now it's considered a seminal work.

I think your main issue here is what you mean by "good". Entertaining? Enjoyable? Exciting? Beautiful? Insightful? Passionate? Intense? Profound? Does it need an exceptional script, performance, cinematography, lighting, score, visual effect, choreography? Can a documentary be "good"? What about experimental, conceptual, abstract and non-narrative film?
I think one could build a good argument around a given film being objectively good/rich/effective/striking/successful etc. on any of these criteria, but just "good" is far too vague.

"...it's a dialect, and not an accent. The distinction is technical as well as political: Immigrants have accents, natives have dialects; an accent is something you try to lose, a dialect is something you use to define your cultural and geographical heritage. "
Uhhhmmmmmmmmmm no. A dialect consists in the words you use; an accent is the way you pronounce them. Pronouncing "man" in any way at all is an accent. Replacing "man" with another word (eg. "blood", "dude" etc) would be a feature/indicator of dialect.
Both serve to define geographic, cultural and class identity. And both can be "lost" or "exaggerated" as situations require - for example it is often cited that women in groups of same-gender strangers will modify their accent and dialect towards the regional standard and "up" the class scale to enhance status, while men will modify away from the regional standard and "down" the class scale to achieve the same thing - the assumption (which I question) being that women want their peers to see them as sophisticated and men want their peers to see them as down-to-earth.
In any case, researchers would need to argue that eg. "mahn" is a different word from "man", with different etymological roots and connotative connections, in order for this particular set of linguistic features to be called a "dialect". I think that would be quite hard.

I know that feeling, friend. You get into a cycle of self-hatred and you get depressed. Might be worth talking to a doctor about it if this is a regular thing or if it's getting more intense. A fix could be as simple as a diet change.
However, in the meantime, recognise that: 1) while you may be acting badly, at least you're aware of it. This is Step One for everyone. 2) if you're treating the people you love badly, at least you have people that you love. This is not something to take lightly. You are capable of love and you genuinely want to treat these people better. That's a good thing.
Also, your quest begins when you consider that the thing that is undesirable is not you but your behaviour. And that is something that it's much easier to contemplate changing than changing you. Having these feelings and behaving like this have a cause somewhere - psychological, chemical, hormonal, spiritual, I don't know. But these causes are addressable. That's (at least part of) what mindfulness is. It's about knowing what is and accepting it - maybe with a view to improving or modifying it - rather than wishing it were otherwise and just futilely railing against it because it's not.
Lastly, try having some compassion for yourself. Not feeling sorry for yourself, but compassion. Imagine that it was someone you truly loved who was behaving like this. How would you feel towards them? Would you still be able to see the person underneath? Would you still love them even if you didn't like their behaviour? Would you turn your back on them or see their anguish and try to help? You are just as worthy of your own compassion as anyone else.
NON-BUDDHIST PRO TIP: when you do something you're not proud of, don't think of it as bad/awful/despicable, but rather as "a step backward" along the path to stopping this cycle. It's a subtle thing, but it really helped me to think of these things as temporary stumbles or setbacks rather than stains that I will bear forever. Honestly, that's also a much more accurate way to view them.

That's an interesting reading. I do think I disagree with you though, and I'll tell you why: in the "first ending" you are identifying with the father very closely. You call out how brutal and shocking is the choice that the father has to make (I would call it a pragmatic choice rather than a moral one, though). But when you talk about the second ending, you have lost that identification and talk about it being all about "bad timing" as if you have stepped back out of the scene.
SPOILERS FOLLOW: Instead, I see the first ending as a tragic but pragmatic choice. They have given up hope. The mist goes on forever. They cannot survive. With only four bullets, only four of them can take the quick way out, so the father steps up and does the hardest thing - he shoots the other passengers including his son and steps outside the car to meet his fate, knowing that he has spared them the agony of being eaten or whatever.
But then he doesn't die. The mist clears. The soldiers turn up. The import of this is not that they all would have lived if he'd waited five minutes. The true horror is in the fact that he *now has to live with having killed his son*. He's never going to recover from that.
And if that weren't enough, we've also stepped from a nightmare world of monsters and violence where people killing other people is a matter of survival, back into the prosaic world where he hasn't just spared his passengers from a fate worse than death; he's just *murdered four people, including his son*. Here comes order and civilisation marching up the street. And that throws into sharp relief The Lord of the Flies -style breakdown of civilisation that took place in the supermarket and everything that followed. I think this is especially important when looking at the narrative that revolves around the crazy religious lady.
So, for me, the "Darth Vader scream" is the sound of the man he was realising the man he has been forced to become. It is the sound of his mind and soul irreparably shattering. And it makes the "first ending" even more brutal, shocking and brave by throwing it back into a naturalistic perspective.
I think that was what Darabont was aiming for - to re-frame his essentially otherworldly/fantastical movie back into the real world and thereby shed a bright new light on all the hard choices he forced his characters to make, and in this particular case, to make those characters *own* the consequences of their actions. It originally came from the expense of making film reels for cinema exhibition. The distributor would print so many copies of the film and use them for the US theatrical release, then pack them up and ship them to Europe. After the European run, the reels would be distributed to the Far East and South America. This is where we get the Region 1/2/3 thing on DVDs and it has screwed up the gifts management side of things no end as we move towards 100% digital distribution.
Today, it is a way to optimise marketing spend. Global campaigns are very expensive and a staggered release means the distributor can manage spend on a territory-by-territory basis based on the performance of the film in previous territories.

"BBC English" and "The Queen's English" are colloquial terms for "Standard English" which is a language. "American English" and "International English" are language variants or (less accurately) dialects. These terms refer to the words used - and by extension, their spelling - not the way they are pronounced.
There is (technically) no such thing as "British English".
Many East Coast US accents are often said to be "closer to the original accent" than RP. This is because the language of the English Court at the time of the colonisation of North America had features like pronounced terminal "R"s and sharper "A"s. This change is not because of phonemic shift in RP, but rather because the Court moved geographically and so its prevailing accent changed.
Terminal "R"s and sharper "A"s are still strong in accents from the North West of England (eg. Liverpool) and the West Country (eg. Bristol). It is no coincidence that these are areas where a lot of emigrants to the US came from, especially as Bristol and Liverpool have long been maritime cities.
The US fondness for removing "u"s and similar simplifications of spelling come from Webster's efforts to standardise the language, starting with "A Compendious Dictionary of the English Language" of 1806. You have to remember that the concept of "correct spelling" was even then still relatively new - prior to the mid C18th, pretty much any spelling was fine. People argue to this day about the influence of Puritanism and American experimentation in education on the formation of American English variant spelling.

Not an expert, but my tuppence-worth: isn't there a difference between an injured being and one that is helpless and in the actual process of dying? There was a post the other day about a poisoned rat dying in agony and confusion and my internal reaction was, "well if that was me, I'd want someone to kill me quickly." I know, I know: unjustified anthropomorphism, but I naturally approach compassion from an empathetic direction.
Anyway, my point is that the rat would die within agony-filled hours or days anyway and nothing could alleviate its simple physical suffering save euthanising or possibly anaesthetising. The bird could be nursed, its injuries treated to make it more comfortable, and food and water could be provided to keep it alive. In this way, its suffering could be relieved while maintaining its life. The rat's could not.
This opens a whole can of worms for me. Is euthanasia ever justified for dying, agonised creatures (and humans)? Where do we draw these lines? What about medically extending the life of a creature or human who is suffering agony? Is "withholding treatment" to "let nature take its course" just copping out? What about the patient's wishes - if the rat could talk and were pleading for an end to its pain, should we ignore it? The whole gamut of Medical Ethics lies spread before us.
I'm not sure whether it is "right action" or not, but faced with a creature suffering like this bird, I would first assess its condition to see if I or anyone else could relieve its suffering without harming it, but if that was not possible, I would end its life humanely. I understand the "existence is suffering" point and the analogy of killing a child to prevent future suffering, but I'm simply unable to see myself just watching a creature suffer its way to death for hours and then afterwards sitting back and thinking, "well, existence is suffering, and the suffering-density over time is irrelevant, so I did the right thing there."

Hi brother. A lot of people have been focusing on the "penis" part of this, but I'd like to focus on the "depression" part. I experience the same self-hatred around my own reasons. Fortunately for me, my bouts of depression - although very intense and regular - are very short-lived (about a week every six or eight weeks). I feel for you having a long period of depression. For me, when I am depressed, my Practice goes out the window. When you hate yourself, it's very difficult to find the energy to try to improve yourself, and when your mind is filled with that, there's not much room for anything else.
I find that it helps me to identify the depression as something that happens to me, not something that defines me. I know that when I'm depressed I say and do things that I would never do or say outside of the depression - it's like a different person is living my life. I almost think of it like being a werewolf or the Hulk or something (not really, but it can be a helpful concept to help me step back a bit). When people say "I'm sorry I did/said that - I wasn't feeling myself", I think that's what they're getting at.
For me, dealing with this side of my life started with recognising that it was a problem. That helped me start to "accept" that I was struggling with depression (rather than "suffering from" it) and that it was okay for me to have this problem - it doesn't make me weak or a bad person, it's just one of the things I have in my life, and everybody has something. It's good to see that's the stage you are at - you're on the right path.
Practice does help a lot ... if you can practice from inside the depression you're doing very well.
I would humbly suggest that you need to see a therapist (which you're doing) to help you work through the depressed thoughts, and you also need to see a medical doctor to make sure there isn't an easily-fixed hormonal or chemical side to it (the depression part, I mean, but a doctor may be able to help you with your penis issue too).

I'm a newbie to SGI too - about six months of practicing - and its good to hear someone else has the same reservations that I do. The person who introduced me took me to visit SGI UK headquarters at Taplow recently and, while everyone I met there was very nice, I couldn't help but find it a little "cultish" and therefore unsettling.
Perhaps I should expand. I'm a former Christian with a degree in Biblical Studies who toured with a Christian rock band in my youth. I really walked the walk. About fourteen years ago I lost my faith and became an atheist, but I still respect others' right to practice religion as they see fit; I'm just not in the market for a new religion myself. I find the practice of Nichiren Buddhism has very tangible benefits for me, some of which I can find rational reasons for, some of which I am currently filing under "selection bias" or in some cases "beyond me right now but I can see myself reaching a point where I understand it". The doctrine that I find irrational or superstitious, I file under "well you're free to believe that, but it's not for me." I'm open to there being a "yet" on the end of that.
But having been brought up a Methodist, I have a very highly attuned cult detection faculty (it's a big part of Methodism). When people tell me to think, believe or do something and worry about understanding it later, I smile, nod politely, and back off. This skepticism is maybe counter-productive in some cases - for example, I refused to chant until I understood in English what I was being encouraged to repeat, and even something as basic as the "nam" part of "nam myoho renge kyo" wasn't something I was comfortable with in my first meeting - in the same way I don't sing hymns or recite the prayers when I attend a Christian wedding for example.
My take on this is that I am on my own personal journey. The sutras and other teachings - and the insight of my friends in my local district - represent a fabulous wealth of wisdom for me to draw on, but they have no meaning for me until I can internalise and understand. I recognise that my understanding will grow with time, and my attitude to particular aspects might even reverse completely - like my attitude to the central doctrines of Christianity did. But for now, I don't internalise what I see as some of the more superstitious aspects. I am very grateful that in my local district I feel very free to do that and to discuss it openly - the polar opposite of my experience as a Christian.
So I think the bottom line is that I identify as a Buddhist on the basis that I am practicing Buddhism, not because I am a member of an organisation. I certainly don't accept any responsibility for, or identification with, ALL of Buddhism. And I don't share many of the views of some of my Buddhist friends.
Perhaps it is relevant that I haven't so far felt ready to accept the Gohonzon, so maybe I'm just a "tourist" or not "really" a Buddhist at all in some people's eyes. But again, there's probably a "yet" on there. I'm cool with that and in my district they are too. But at SGI Taplow and with the quite zealous lady that first introduced me... well I didn't feel that expressing my reservations would be accepted quite so readily. My reaction to that is, "whatever" and a shrug. Maybe some would argue that I'm holding myself back on the path to enlightenment, but it's a journey not a destination and I'm in no hurry.
Anyway, I hope you continue to find benefit from your practice and I hope you can feel free to reject or at least not identify with what doesn't resonate for you.

Mmmmmmm, no. The Alien is faceless (the lack of eyes forces us to look it in the teeth) and is a force of Nature, yes; but Norman Bates is a sick young man and in the final shot, a victim who wears his mother's face. The crew of the Nostromo are motivated by survival; Arbogast et al are motivated by solving the mystery and finding the missing girl. Alien uses a mix of cinema verite (unscripted dialogue etc) and B-movie (cat-scare) techniques; Psycho uses noire (lighting/cinematography and detective tropes) and pure Hitchcockian ones (eg. the red-herring of the stolen money, shadowing in the shots of taxidermy etc). There is a Freudian aspect to both, but it is body-horror fear of (male) rape and impregnation in Alien and some form of Oedipal arrested development in Psycho.
I suppose you could argue that they're are both Haunted House narratives, but that's more a common genre than any direct connection.
